cluster in US East and replicate that cluster in and in a few clicks and it's one of the
reasons that we're seeing so many customers moving on to AWS so now let's
talk a little bit about elastic MapReduce or EMR EMR is meant to make it
easy to run Hadoop on AWS and Hadoop of course is an open source framework for
parallel processing very large amounts of data across a cluster of machines in our case that's a cluster of Amazon ec2
instances um ours is we started in 2009
and since then we've been used by many thousands of customers we've launched over 5 million clusters I believe that's
the data point that we shared earlier this year the number is now significantly more than 5 million and as
you can see from some of the the customers on the slide they really span a wide range of industries and verticals
so to give you a couple of examples in the media space we an advertising space we see organizations correlating ad
impression Logs with clickstream data to deliver better and more relevant advertising in the retail space we have
companies like amazon.com using EMR to power product recommendations in the
life science of space there's a tremendous amount of genomics processing that's happening and other bioinformatics research and so that the
use cases are really quite varied and in any in any industry there's really a
variety of things that you can be doing with with tools like EMR so let's talk a
little bit about how it works one simplistic model for how EMR works is as follows so first you upload your
data and your processing application to Amazon s3 which is our storage service you can write your application in in
Java you can write it in hive or Pig or a variety of other languages you then
come to the Amazon EMR service you can use our SDKs or API our console or a
command-line interface to configure your cluster so first you would choose which
region you want to launch your cluster in for example the US or Europe or Japan or Australia you then select the Hadoop
distribution we support for different distributions on EMR currently you tell EMR how many instances or how many nodes
you want to provision so you might want three nodes or you might want a thousand it just you make your selection you also
select what types of instances you want to use so for example if you're doing image processing you might want to use
high CPU instances if you are running an HBase application you might want to use a high i/o or a cluster compute instance
type and you make some other selections like around security and access and other other custom settings if you want
to install additional applications there's a very easy way to do that you then tell you Marv to launch your cluster after the processing is complete
the cluster will transfer the output back to Amazon s3 or whatever location
you specify if you tell EMR to leave the
cluster running we'll leave it running and you can give it additional work otherwise will automatically tear the cluster down so that you stop paying for
it and just a quick note that if if you don't want to use s3 and you want to for example run a persistent long-running
cluster and just use HDFS you can just write your data directly to HDFS and pull it out when the job is done one of
the things that's unique about doing Hadoop in the cloud and using Amar's that you can easily resize your clusters
so this can be very useful if you have end-of-the-month processing if you do batch processing at night or you need
more capacity at certain hours of the day than others it's very easy to add instances to your cluster and then take
them away when you no longer need them another thing is very unique about EMR andy mars architecture is that it allows
you to leverage something called ec2 spot instances and spot instances are essentially unused ec2 capacity that you
place a bid price on the spot market price changes every hour based on supply and demand and by using spot instances
you can save 50% to 80% off of the on-demand price for brands on ec2 the
catch with spot is that if the market price goes above your bid price you'll lose those instances so to accommodate
that EMR has a special architecture in which there is a certain class of slave node that does
not run HDFS the Hadoop distributed file system we call those task nodes and they're ideal for spot because you if
you lose the capacity you do not lose your data on HDFS so an EMR cluster essentially has three nodes master node
core node that is running HDFS and task node that is not and you can run all or
part of your cluster on spot but we find that many customers in production are using spot in order to significantly say
to save a significant amount of money and also speed up their processing by a significant amount one of the other
things that's a little unusual about EMR and it takes in might take a moment to to under to appreciate what what this
means for your processing is that if you have your data in Amazon s3 you can launch multiple EMR clusters pointing to
the same data set so the reason I say this is a little unusual is that most of the time on premise you have a single
cluster maybe you have one or two clusters and you you kind of treat the cluster you provision it for the lowest
common denominator and you have to tune your applications for the cluster that you have in the EMR context you
provision clusters and you optimize them for a given application so you might have one cluster that's optimized for
CPU another that's optimized for i/o and you split your applications across the
clusters and that way your clusters are much more efficient and you don't actually have to replicate the same
dataset across multiple clusters you can use s3 as bris as a single version of the truth you can launch your entire
cluster in an amazon virtual private cloud which is a logically isolated section of the AWS network we also have
other tools to control access and permissions and finally when you're done
with a cluster if you if you transfer the output to Amazon s3 which is what many of our customers will do you can
terminate the cluster and stop paying for it that way you continue to use Amazon s3 for storage and you use EMR
and compute only when you tree we need compute now I just want to talk
for a minute or two about why do people use EMR and then and then we're going to go over to MicroStrategy so first of all
people use some of our customers use EMR because it's easy you can launch a cluster in minutes that could be a three

EMR handles node provisioning Hadoop configuration tuning setup all of those
